newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy defends European role in Mideast peace talks.
newsitem.headline: Italy defends European role in Mideast peace talks.

text.p: Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini on Monday defended Europe's role in Middle East peace talks after the United States shut it out of a summit in Washington.

"Tonight's meeting of the European troika with President (Yasser) Arafat in Luxembourg...underlines the role of Europe in the Middle East peace process, especially since it is being held before the Washington summit," Dini told Reuters.
He said the meeting was being held "at the express request of Italy".

The European Union's troika made up of Ireland, Italy and the Netherlands -- the 15-nation bloc's past, current and next presidents -- was due to meet the Palestinian president at around 1930 GMT, a foreign ministry official said.
The meeting would be followed by bilateral talks between Dini and Arafat, the official added.
Arafat was expected to travel on to Washinton for Tuesday's summit but has not yet officially confirmed that he will attend.
President Bill Clinton summoned the leaders of Israel, the PLO, Egypt and Jordan after a wave of violence sparked by the opening of an Israeli tunnel in the Arab Old City of Jerusalem.
But he left out the Europeans, despite intensive lobbying by France and Italy for a bigger role in Middle East peace moves.

Dini said that the troika formula confirmed the EU's "desire to express itself with a single voice". Italy publicly upbraided France earlier this year for conducting solo Middle East peace efforts without consulting its EU partners.
Dini said the troika had urged Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy at a meeting last week in New York to make "concrete, unilateral gestures...to unblock the peace process".
"We will also be asking President Arafat tonight for an assurance of the will on both sides to proceed along the path of peace," Dini said.
